election_record.label: New York 1817 Governor, Special

overview.note: "The Election, in this State, opens to-day, and under circumstances never before witnessed since the people divided into two great political parties. There is but one candidate for the first office, and in most of the counties, the strife for members of the Legislature is confined to the present ruling party. It is not probable that many of the federalists will go to the polls, except in counties and districts where federal candidates are nominated. --This course is believed to be dictated by sound policy--It is not, as Mr. Coleman would infer, that 'federalism is abadndoned in the Western District'--but that opposition, after what we have experienced, is considered worse than useless--serving only to draw out and consolidate the whole force of democracy, which otherwise would, from its inconsistency, divide and fall to pieces." Ontario Repository (Canandaigua, NY). April 29, 1817.
Some sources list Paul Coffin as "Paul Griffin."

sub_unit.name: Clinton
sub_unit.note: The New York Columbian lists 506 votes for DeWitt Clinton.

sub_unit.name: Saratoga
sub_unit.note: The Independent American (Ballston Spa, NY) of May 14, 1817 did not include vote totals for the towns of Galway and Northumberland. Based on the total vote for the two towns (174), and an estimation based on the votes for State Senate in the same two towns, DeWitt Clinton likely received 104 votes in Galway and 70 in Northumberland.

sub_unit.name: Schenectady
sub_unit.note: The Official Canvass of Votes lists DeWitt Clinton with 566 votes though the town totals add up to 568.

sub_unit.name: Coeymans
sub_unit.note: "No returns have yet been received at the Clerk's office from the town of Coeymans." The Albany Gazette (Albany, NY). May 7, 1817.

sub_unit.name: Westerloo
sub_unit.note: The Albany Gazette (Albany, NY) lists 120 votes for DeWitt Clinton.

sub_unit.name: Chenango
sub_unit.note: The Official Canvass of Votes lists 1027 votes for DeWitt Clinton though the town votes listed in The Norwich Journal (Norwich, NY) and the Oxford Gazette (Oxford, NY) add up to 1025.
The New York Columbian lists 1026 votes for DeWitt Clinton.

sub_unit.name: Gilford
sub_unit.note: The Oxford Gazette (Oxford, NY) lists the town of Gilford with the name Eastern.

sub_unit.name: Delaware
sub_unit.note: No returns were reported from Colchester and Hancock.

sub_unit.name: Orange
sub_unit.note: The New York Columbian lists 42 votes for Peter B. Porter.

sub_unit.name: Sullivan
sub_unit.note: The Ulster Plebeian lists 172 votes for DeWitt Clinton though the town totals add up to 272.

sub_unit.name: Poughkeepsie
sub_unit.note: The votes for Lord Castlereah and Prince Regent were not reported in the Official Canvass.

sub_unit.name: Red Hook
sub_unit.note: The scattering votes in Red Hook were not broken down and were therefore rejected in the Official Canvass.

sub_unit.name: New York
sub_unit.note: Dennis Doyle received 1 vote as Dennis H. Doyle and 1 vote as Dennis O. Doyle.

sub_unit.name: One
sub_unit.note: The New York Columbian lists 116 votes for DeWitt Clinton.

sub_unit.name: Queens
sub_unit.note: The New York Columbian lists 283 votes for DeWitt Clinton.

sub_unit.name: Westchester
sub_unit.note: Annals and Recollections of Oneida County lists Peter B. Porter with 290 votes with three towns reporting no votes. The Albany Argus (Albany, NY) lists 295 votes. The missing 5 votes were probably cast in South Salem, New Castle or Poundridge town.
Nathan Merritt received 1 vote as Nathaniel Merritt.

sub_unit.name: Cayuga
sub_unit.note: The New York Columbian lists 1974 votes for DeWitt Clinton.

sub_unit.name: Oneida
sub_unit.note: The Official State Wide Canvass as given in The Albany Argus (Albany, NY) of June 10 and 13, lists 33 scattering votes for Governor in Oneida county. However, Annual and Recollections of Oneida County lists 36 scattering votes. It appears that three scattering votes, most likely in either Steuben or Trenton towns, were not transferred onto the Official State Wide Canvass.

sub_unit.name: Paris
sub_unit.note: Annals and Recollections of Oneida County lists 8 votes for "others".

sub_unit.name: Sangerfield
sub_unit.note: Annals and Recollections of Oneida County lists 2 votes for "others".

sub_unit.name: Whitestown
sub_unit.note: Annals and Recollections of Oneida County lists 17 votes for "others".

sub_unit.name: Onondaga
sub_unit.note: The New York Columbian lists 4617 votes for DeWitt Clinton.

sub_unit.name: Oswego
sub_unit.note: Annual and Recollections of Oneida County lists 262 votes for DeWitt Clinton and 7 scattering votes Governor. The Official State Wide Canvass as listed in The Albany Argus (Albany, NY), June 10 and 13, gives 332 votes for DeWitt Clinton and 41 scattering votes in Oswego county, including 37 votes for John Tayler. Votes for Clinton in Mexico and Redfield towns seem to have been counted twice in The Albany Argus (Albany, NY), resulting in an incorrect 332 vote total for Clinton. Additionally, the 37 scattering votes for John Tayler seem to be incorrectly listed. No single source gives both the names of candidates receiving scattering votes and the specific towns in which their votes were cast. However, by crossreferencing sources that give candidate names with vote totals but no locations (The Albany Argus (Albany, NY), June 10 and 13), and those that list locations with vote totals but not the names of candidates ("Annual and Recollections of Oneida County), it seems most likely that Peter B. Porter received one vote in Mexico, Abraham Clute three votes in Volney, and John Tayler three votes in Redfield. Much of the confusion in this election is due to the fact that Oswego and Oneida counties voted together for governor, and many sources did not separate (or incorrectly separated) the two in reporting returns.

sub_unit.name: Seneca
sub_unit.note: Peter B. Porter received 13 votes as Peter D. Porter.
DeWitt Clinton received 1 vote as DeWitt Clinten.
The New York Columbian lists 144 votes for Peter B. Porter.

sub_unit.name: Tioga
sub_unit.note: The New York Columbian lists 500 votes for DeWitt Clinton.
